transcripts.text: So Tulsi Gabbard appeared on MSNBC recently and was interviewed by Yasmin Vazogian.  And as always happens when Tulsi Gabbard appears on any corporate media network, Vazogian brought up Tulsi's 2017 trip with Dennis Kucinich to Syria, where she ended up meeting with the Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad.  So let's watch this clip.  Please pay attention to how disingenuous Vizogian is.  Please pay attention to how many times she interrupts Tulsi Gabbard and doesn't let her make the point.  It happens repeatedly.  And just let's listen to this.  And I'll get my thoughts about halfway through.
There's on 9-11 to every family that lost a loved one on that day.
Congresswoman, do you not believe that the same could be said for your meeting with Bashar al-Assad?
I don't know how you could equate that.  We're talking about a president that is directly...
That you would be meeting with the leader of Syria who could feasibly be responsible for the killings of over half a million people who ordered the chemical attacks on children in his own country?

I will never apologize for doing all that I can to prevent more of my brothers and sisters in uniform from being sent into harm's way to fight another regime change war, the likes of which we have seen in Iraq and Libya and Syria that have taken so many of our service members' lives, that has taken so many of our taxpayer dollars out of the pockets of people in this country, people who are suffering, people in places like Detroit, like Flint, Michigan, communities across this country, what to speak of the suffering that's been caused.  So if that means... meeting with a dictator, meeting with an adversary in order to accomplish that mission of keeping the American people safe, making sure our troops are not continuing to be sent on these wasteful wars, putting their lives at risk and making sure we've got the resources for the American people.  I'll do what is necessary.  And frankly, that's the kind of commander in chief we need that truly has the courage, just as we've seen in our country's past, how President Kennedy met with Khrushchev how Roosevelt not only met with Stalin, a murderous dictator who killed
millions
of
people, excuse me, sorry, let

me finish, who met not only with Stalin, who killed millions of people, but actually allied with him.  Why?  Because it was in the best interest of our country and the American people to bring about an end to that war.  So no, if it means meeting with dictators, if it means working with people who do things that we find...
They're meeting with Bashar al-Assad, but not necessarily meeting with the leader of Saudi Arabia or supporting or having a relationship with them.
Sure.  You're mixing two different things up.  I'm talking about having a meeting.
I don't think I'm mixing two different things up.  I'm just trying to get clarity on it because there seems to be some inconsistencies in your views of it.

There's no inconsistency whatsoever.  Having a meeting for the pursuit of our national security and peace is one thing.  I would meet with the leader of Saudi Arabia, with leaders of Iran, with leaders of North Korea in that pursuit of national security, keeping the American people unsafe.  The difference between that and what Donald Trump has done and continues to do is he has cozied up, allied with and supported Saudi Arabia.  in their support of al-Qaeda and in support of this genocidal war in Yemen that continues to this day, an illegal war that Congress has not authorized, that's killed thousands of innocent Yemeni people, and that's caused millions more to suffer.  So you're talking about... two very different things here.  But you know what?

These are issues.  I hear you on this.  I hear you on this.  So I want to go with this for a moment.  So when sitting down with someone like Bashar al-Assad in Syria, do you confront him directly and say, why do you order chemical attacks on your own people?  Why do you cause the killings of over half a million people in your country?

Look, you know, I want to break this down to what we're talking about.  I want to break this down to what we're talking about here today because you're talking about a meeting that took place, what, three years ago?  And every time I come back here on MSNBC, you guys talk to me about these issues.  It sounds like these are talking points that Kamala Harris and her campaign are feeding you because she's refusing to address the questions.

It's important, I think, for the American people to have context about your foreign policy issues and where you stand.  If you're leading with foreign policy and you're running for the president of the United States, a meeting with Bashar al-Assad, which I'm sure you understand, is a very controversial meeting to take.

So I just wanted to stop here to also make note of the fact that Nancy Pelosi and John Kerry are two people who have also met with Bashar al-Assad.  But isn't it odd that the corporate media never brings up those meetings ever?  Could it possibly be because Pelosi and Kerry work for the benefit of the military-industrial complex, so their meetings with foreign dictators are forgivable, while peace candidates like Denis Kucinich and Tulsi Gabbard doing the exact same thing are seen as traitorous?  This is something that Tulsi doesn't mention, but I really wish she did bring it up more often and point to this double standard.  Anyway, let's listen to the rest of this.
Of course, every anchor has a different perspective and different questions to ask of you.

Every single time for three years.  This is where the propaganda comes in, because I've talked about this a lot for the last three years.  And I've talked about how.  as a soldier, I served in a field medical unit in Iraq.  where every single day I saw the very high human cost of war.  Every single day, the first thing that I did was go through a list name by name of every single American casualty and injury that had occurred the day before.  So I will not apologize to you or to anyone, anyone.  Nobody is asking you to apologize.  Let me finish.  Let me finish for doing all that I can.  all that I can to prevent our country from continuing to make these perpetual wrong decisions that have taken a toll on the lives of my brothers and sisters in uniform.  I will continue to do all that I can to make sure that we end these wasteful regime change wars that have taken such a toll on all of us and that have made our country less safe.  And if that means having a meeting with a dictator, if that means trying to meet with Kim Jong-un in North Korea to de-escalate tensions and remove this nuclear threat from our country and our people.  Whatever the crisis is, we've got to have a leader with the courage to do the right thing for the American people, putting their interests ahead of everything else.  That is what I'm focused on.  And that's at the center of my foreign policy and the leadership that I'll bring as president.

I certainly am not asking you to apologize for your service.  I'm very thankful for your service at that.  And I don't think anybody is asking you to apologize for your service.  This is more a conversation and asking you questions to explain the decisions that you've made in the past and the statements that you've made in the past with regards to your foreign policy views as you are running for president of the United States.  Congresswoman, I thank you for your time.  Tulsi Gabbard, very much appreciate your time.

So there you go, folks.  I think that this was pretty great.  Tulsi Gabbard really put Vazogian in her place.  And the thing that makes Tulsi Gabbard different is that she actually has seen the cost of war firsthand.  When corporate media hacks like Vazogian try to attack her and make her look like a traitor, as the corporate media always does to any peace candidate of any party whenever they embrace a peaceful foreign policy, when Vazogian tried to do that with Gabbard, she just exposed herself for the deceptive liar that she is.  Vazogian doesn't know what it's like to serve, as Gabbard has, and she hasn't put her life on the line serving this nation like Tulsi Gabbard has.  So when all of these actual traitors in the corporate media, the traitors to peace and the traitors to humanity, when they try to paint Tulsi Gabbard in that light, they only expose themselves more.  This is what makes Tulsi Gabbard different.  She's not just on the correct side philosophically.  She's not just beautiful and well-spoken.  She's also actually served this nation and has the credentials to speak about issues of war and peace more than any of the disgraceful, disingenuous corporate stooges who try to attack her.  What this clip shows is that Tulsi is really invincible to these smears.  And beyond that, her message has broad appeal.  A peace message is the one thing that liberals, conservatives, progressives, libertarians, socialists, and yes, even centrists can rally behind.  Peace is the one nonpartisan issue.  And that's why the military industrial complex media is now panicking and trying over and over again to smear Tulsi Gabbard any way possible.  Because if she starts connecting with enough Americans, that puts a lot of money at risk for the merchants of death.
